name: Jesus of Nazareth: A Biography
description: Itinerant preacher who challenged Rome and the Temple — the social revolutionary whose movement outlived every empire that tried to claim him

name: Martin Luther King Jr.: A Biography
description: From Montgomery to Memphis — the preacher who weaponized nonviolence, moved a nation, and was murdered for it

name: Frederick Douglass: A Biography
description: Born enslaved, self-educated, became the most powerful abolitionist voice in America — the man who made the nation confront its founding lie

name: Cesar Chavez: A Biography
description: Farmworker turned labor organizer who proved that the poorest workers could take on the most powerful industry — through strikes, boycotts, and sheer endurance

name: Rosa Parks: A Biography
description: Not a tired seamstress but a trained activist — the woman whose calculated refusal to stand launched 381 days of collective resistance

name: Harvey Milk: A Biography
description: From closeted Wall Street analyst to America's first openly gay elected official — the man who proved that visibility is power

name: Emmeline Pankhurst: A Biography
description: Deeds not words — the woman who decided that polite petitions were useless and that windows needed breaking

name: Desmond Tutu: A Biography
description: Archbishop against apartheid — the moral voice who wept with victims, confronted mobs, and asked a nation to choose truth over vengeance

name: Malala Yousafzai: A Biography
description: Shot in the head at 15 for wanting to go to school — the girl who told the Taliban that bullets cannot silence ideas
